channel.title: BBC News

item.title: How is your hospital doing as NHS battles to bring down waiting times?
item.description: Use our interactive tracker to see if treatment waits are getting better at your local hospital

item.title: Drug for rare disease brings 'joy and hope'
item.description: A teenage patient who helped discover a rare condition is the first to benefit from a new treatment.

item.title: Weight loss jabs study begins after reports of pancreas issues
item.description: There have been hundreds of cases of acute pancreatitis in people who have also taken Mounjaro, Ozempic and Wegovy.

item.title: Womb lining test offers miscarriage hope to women
item.description: The test can measure whether an abnormal reaction in the womb could make pregnancy loss more likely.

item.title: Ransomware attack contributed to patient's death
item.description: An NHS trust in London confirms an unexpected patient death during the cyber attack on 3 June 2024.

item.title: Watchdog 'acted irrationally' over gender clinic, court told
item.description: A former nurse and a mother claim the watchdog should have imposed conditions on the clinic.

item.title: I lost £15,000 after going to an IVF middleman
item.description: Companies that act as "middlemen" between patients and doctors are not regulated by the fertility watchdog.

item.title: At-home cervical screening tests offered in England
item.description: The home tests will be offered so that women can check for cervical cancer without visiting a GP.

item.title: Millions of children at risk as vaccine uptake stalls
item.description: A global study finds large numbers of children are unvaccinated against diseases like measles, tuberculosis and polio, which makes outbreaks more likely.

item.title: Strict rules as GPs start to prescribe weight loss jab Mounjaro
item.description: NHS England says the first patients able to get the jab will be those most in need.

item.title: How to stay safe at festivals this summer
item.description: The UKHSA and Somerset Council have put together a list on how to stay safe at festivals this summer.

item.title: Stop telling me to lower my cortisol - it's making me stressed!
item.description: Can social media hacks really help bring down your cortisol levels?

item.title: 'Our sister died of cancer because of our mum's conspiracy theories'
item.description: Paloma Shemirani’s brothers say she refused chemotherapy because of their mother’s beliefs.

item.title: Why today's assisted dying vote is so significant
item.description: The debate around assisted dying has been a polarised one - and there are still hurdles to cross before it will be a reality here.

item.title: MPs vote to decriminalise abortion for women in England and Wales
item.description: The vote to decriminalise the procedure is the biggest change to abortion laws in England and Wales for nearly 60 years.

item.title: How does a £1.6m fine affect an NHS trust?
item.description: How will the largest fine over maternity deaths impact the NHS and the families it failed?

item.title: My dad gave me a kidney - now I can have my dream wedding
item.description: Kieran Innes was worried he would have to curtail his future plans when his kidneys failed.

item.title: Mood swings fuelled Heston Blumenthal's genius. But the highs got higher and the lows got darker
item.description: A new BBC documentary looks at how a diagnosis of bipolar disorder at 57 changed the celebrity chef's life.

item.title: I'm an NHS leader - but mum still suffered at hands of health service because she was black
item.description: NHS Confederation chair Lord Adebowale says his mother's death illustrates inequalities in the system.

item.title: Why are pollen levels making hay fever so bad this year?
item.description: As pollen levels rise, what are the best ways to treat hay fever symptoms, and other useful advice.

item.title: We always joked dad looked nothing like his parents - then we found out why
item.description: Matthew's father died late last year - before learning the truth about his family history.

item.title: World-first blood cancer therapy to be given on NHS
item.description: It sneaks toxic drugs inside cancer cells to hit them hard while minimising side-effects.

item.title: Handwritten notes reveal Churchill's penicillin concern ahead of D-Day
item.description: Handwritten notes show the wartime prime minister's frustration over slow penicillin production.

item.title: Hospital backlog drops to lowest level in two years
item.description: But the NHS in England is still well below its target for seeing patients within 18 weeks.

item.title: MPs set to vote on decriminalising abortion in England and Wales
item.description: Women would never be prosecuted for terminating a pregnancy under proposed new laws.

item.title: We quit our jobs, sold our home twice and spent 10 years fighting for the truth
item.description: A NHS trust and hospital manager have been found guilty of health and safety failings over the death of Alice Figueiredo.

item.title: Cervical screening invites to change in England
item.description: Invitations be sent out by the NHS every five years instead of every three for women aged 25-49 in England, if they have a negative test.

item.title: What does hot weather do to the body?
item.description: Hot weather during the summer can affect anyone, but some people run a greater risk of serious harm.

item.title: Why are pollen levels making hay fever so bad this year?
item.description: As pollen levels rise, what are the best ways to treat hay fever symptoms, and other useful advice.

item.title: What to do if you think someone has heat exhaustion or heatstroke
item.description: Know the signs and what to do if someone is unwell in hot weather.

item.title: Hot weather: How to sleep in the heat
item.description: Simple tips to help you get a good night's sleep during hot weather.

item.title: Six ways to keep your home and yourself cool in hot weather
item.description: Six simple things you can do to help keep your house cool when temperatures rise.

item.title: The English neighbourhood that claims to hold the secret to fixing the NHS
item.description: With public satisfaction in the NHS just 21%, one area has a plan to shake up its services that could reduce GP waiting lists, as well as unblock hospital beds - but can it really work nationwide?

item.title: Why are disposable vapes being banned and how harmful is vaping?
item.description: It will be illegal to sell or supply disposable vapes from 1 June 2025.

item.title: Labour's plan for benefits throws up a bigger dilemma
item.description: The debate has sparked a wider dilemma about the broader purpose of welfare

item.title: First place in British Isles set to approve right to die
item.description: Laws in the Isle of Man to let terminally ill adults end their own lives are in the last stages of debate.

item.title: Generation K: The disturbing rise of ketamine abuse among young people
item.description: Increasing numbers of young people are using the drug, experts say. The health impacts can be catastrophic.

item.title: Assisted dying bill: What is in proposed law?
item.description: The proposed law would allow some terminally ill adults to end their own lives. But there are requirements.

item.title: 'My first cervical screening was over before I knew it'
item.description: The BBC speaks to six people about their first cervical screening, and what they wish they'd known beforehand.

item.title: Is the system letting down people who were harmed by Covid vaccines?
item.description: People affected by rare blood clots say they feel they have been airbrushed out of the pandemic.

item.title: How will weight-loss drugs change our relationship with food?
item.description: The rise of these treatments has major implications for how we think about obesity, says James Gallagher.

item.title: NHS needs better plan around weight loss jabs, warn experts
item.description: Experts call for an urgent review of obesity treatment services amid booming demand for weight loss jabs.

item.title: How many of us will end up being diagnosed with ADHD?
item.description: Experts suggest that the number of people with ADHD is actually going to remain steady.

item.title: The junior doctors' strikes may be over. But is trouble ahead?
item.description: The end of the pay dispute sounded too good to be true. And now some are wondering if it might be.

item.title: Why we might never know the truth about ultra-processed foods
item.description: Experts can’t agree how exactly they affect us and it’s not clear that science will give us an answer.

item.title: Are weight-loss injections the answer to obesity?
item.description: The appeal is clear - but should we be turning to appetite-suppressing injections?

item.title: The Covid Inquiry Podcast: 'I wasn't the decision maker'
item.description: The Inquiry hears from the lead of the test and trace unit

item.title: Cash to isolate 'would have cut Covid deaths'
item.description: Baroness Dido Harding tells Covid inquiry Rishi Sunak blocked higher support payments.

item.title: Johnson wanted tighter Covid rules, inquiry hears
item.description: In his diaries, Lord Vallance wrote that ex-PM thought rules were not ruthless enough.

item.title: Hancock criticises 'wholly naive' Covid inquiry
item.description: The former health secretary was giving evidence about medical equipment deals during the pandemic.

item.title: Mone accuses Covid inquiry of 'cover-up'
item.description: She says husband Doug Barrowman and her are targets of a "politically motivated witch hunt".

item.title: Michael Gove denies trying to circumvent Dyson ventilator checks
item.description: Former cabinet minister says it would be ludicrous to suggest he tried to shortcut safety checks in the pandemic.

item.title: How does the Covid inquiry work?
item.description: The inquiry has heard from politicians, civil servants, public health experts and bereaved families.

item.title: Michelle Mone-linked PPE firm evidence to be heard in private
item.description: Covid inquiry says hearings into the firm, led by Michelle Mone's husband, must be held in closed session.

item.title: Large UK-wide pandemic preparedness tests planned this year
item.description: The stress test will involve thousands of people to help the UK prepare for potential future threats.

item.title: Families failed by Covid jabs tell inquiry of pain
item.description: They said there was no support after the death and harm suffered by their loved ones.

item.title: NHS hours from PPE running out in Covid - Hancock
item.description: Former health secretary tells inquiry some healthcare settings did run out - "and it was awful".

item.title: Covid inquiry told Treasury blocked NHS bed request
item.description: NHS England chief executive Amanda Pritchard says the decision, in July 2020, was very disappointing.

item.title: Covid inquiry told top NHS doctor was terrified
item.description: Sir Stephen Powis says points-based tool was drawn up should need to prioritise patients have arisen.

item.title: How close were hospitals to collapse in Covid?
item.description: The Covid inquiry restarts its live hearings this week, after senior staff in the NHS revealed just how close some hospitals were to collapse

item.title: Covid inquiry told of trust do-not-resuscitate rule
item.description: Patients' families were “horrified but not surprised” when told the blanket policy had been in place.

item.title: We were not treated as parents, Covid inquiry told
item.description: Mum of premature twins says rigid restrictions on birthing wards during Covid were traumatic.

item.title: Covid ambulance crews faced 'crucial PPE delays'
item.description: Crews say they faced crucial delays trying to save dying patients because of the time it took to put on equipment.

item.title: Covid was like a daily terror attack, doctor tells inquiry
item.description: Covid inquiry hears harrowing testimony from ex-adviser in emergency preparedness at NHS England.

item.title: Covid inquiry rejects clinicians’ anonymity plea
item.description: The UK Health Security Agency argued naming the junior officials could put them at risk of abuse.

item.title: GP to discuss women's health issues online
item.description: The webinars will be run by a GP, who can answer any questions people have about women's health.

item.title: 'Endometriosis is so much more than painful periods'
item.description: Mia Rose Harrison says more awareness of the condition is needed.

item.title: Calls for more support for endometriosis patients
item.description: A campaign group hosts a special event to raise awareness about how the disease affects women.

item.title: Cervical screening changes set to start in Jersey
item.description: New testing methods which are more accurate than previous tests lead to the changes.

item.title: Stop telling me to lower my cortisol - it's making me stressed!
item.description: Can social media hacks really help bring down your cortisol levels?

item.title: New nature health scheme aims to boost well-being
item.description: The RSPB, which helped draw up the scheme, says it has been a success in other parts of the UK.

item.title: Horse charity calls on NHS to fund equine services
item.description: Horses for Wellbeing says the funding would see children get help before they "hit crisis point".

item.title: Nature festival launched at national Park
item.description: Events included wildlife walks, art sessions and the chance to meet an Exmoor pony.

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: James explores the science of a sweet tooth and then gets tips on how to brush like a pro.

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: James Gallagher and the panel consider if an assisted death can guarantee a peaceful end.

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: James Gallagher and the panel discuss the safeguarding implications of the proposed bill

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: In the first of our mini-series we discuss who could get an assisted death under the rules

item.title: Tom Grennan opens up about therapy and imposter syndrome
item.description: Roman Kemp & Tom Grennan dive into therapy on the You About? podcast.

item.title: Lost something? You need an 'FBI mindset' to find it...
item.description: Drs Chris and Xand van Tulleken discuss how to find something when you lose it.

item.title: 'Just speak to someone' - Pimblett's mental health advice
item.description: UFC star Paddy Pimblett speaks with BBC Sport's Sam Harris about dealing with mental health issues.
